instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
water damage in the area of J8300, connector had blown pins 3 and 4, replaced connector and components around it. still no power to Pin 3/4
i have 8.6V to pin 1 of F7700, <CAPACITOR>C7712</CAPACITOR> is .0V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message: Did you check if the fuse is blown? Diode mode on backlight output?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
What voltage is on L7701, pin 1 and 2?

What voltage is on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>, pin 1 and 2?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Is there even image?
Do you get USB activity, or chime?
Assuming yes, or at least <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> is high, post voltages at <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>.
Check continuity to <RESISTOR>R5490</RESISTOR>.
Corroded XW7720 is common failure on Airs...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="larossmann, post: 38796"]What voltage is on L7701, pin 1 and 2?

What voltage is on <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>, pin 1 and 2? [/QUOTE]

L7701 pin 1 .06v and pin 2 .20V
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> Pin 1 .20v and pin 2 .15v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 38811"]Is there even image?
Do you get USB activity, or chime?
Assuming yes, or at least <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> is high, post voltages at <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>.
Check continuity to <RESISTOR>R5490</RESISTOR>.
Corroded XW7720 is common failure on Airs...[/QUOTE]

i have faint image, USB works and i get chime
<TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> all pins less than .10v
<RESISTOR>R5490</RESISTOR> is blank 
and XW7720 is corroded but i think there is a problem before this (but i did run jumper and tested continuity to pin 5 of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>)

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
Sorry, my mistake; it should be <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>, instead of <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR>...
As no voltage at L7701, check F7700 and post <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>/07 voltages.

threads.message:

[/QUOTE]

no worries, thank you for helping.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>
pin 1 .01v
pin 2 3.3v
pin 3 .02v
pin 4  .01v
pin 5 3.3v
pin 6 .01v

F7700 pin 1 8.6v and pin 2 .01v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
"F7700 pin 1 8.6v and pin 2 .01v"
F7700 blown, change it...

Be sure no short on backlight area, before power up the board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Backlight
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 38945"]"F7700 pin 1 8.6v and pin 2 .01v"
F770 blown, change it...

Be sure no short on backlight area, before power up the board.[/QUOTE]

ok thank you
